title: FISH EYES could help find the cure for blindness
title_page: FISH EYES could help find the cure for blindness | Daily Mail Online
text:
Fish eyes may hold the key to a cure for blindness in humans, scientists claim.
In a study on zebrafish, experts identified a trigger that could reverse age-related macular degeneration.
This condition, the leading cause of vision loss around the world, occurs when the retina becomes damaged.
Reducing levels of a brain chemical helps to regrow the affected area of the eye, new research shows.
And this process could happen before damage even occurs, preventing humans from ever needing glasses.
Zebrafish eyes contain a chemical that could reverse age-related macular degeneration - the leading cause of vision loss around the world
Researchers at the Vanderbilt University, Tennessee, found a signal that triggers the repair process in zebrafish.
Their retinas are considered to be the same as humans, with their regrowth started by a reduction in a neurotransmitter.
They found a drop in GABA is the 'trigger for regeneration', suggesting that the same method could work in humans.
Study author Professor James Patton said: 'It might be possible to stimulate human retinas to repair themselves by treating them with a GABA inhibitor.
'The prevailing belief has been the regeneration process in fish retinas is triggered by secreted growth factors.
'But our results indicate the neurotransmitter GABA might initiate the process instead.
The substance helps to regrow the affected area and this process could happen before damage even occurs, preventing humans from ever needing glasses
'All the regeneration models assume a retina must be seriously damaged before regeneration takes place, but our studies indicate GABA can induce this process even in undamaged retinas.'
The retina contains adult stem cells called Muller glia. In fishes, these play a key role in regeneration.
When triggered in zebrafish, these begin to multiply and turn into replacements for the damaged retinal cells.
Muller glia cells are also present in the retinas of humans and other mammals, but don't regenerate.
In the experiments, published in Stem Cell Reports, they found high concentrations of GABA kept the stem cells inactive.
Injecting the fish with drugs that kept high levels of the chemicals in the brain suppressed the regeneration process.
Zebrafish are easily blinded but due to their robust regenerative ability their eyes recover in just 28 days.
